Fig. 7 Modulating the electronic structure of MoS3 catalyst via heteroatom doping for Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction: A theoretical study Xuedan Song Software Investigation Data curation Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Qing Zhang Investigation Writing – review & editing Conceptualization Hanyu Xu Investigation Writing – review & editing Chang Yu Supervision Funding acquisition Jieshan Qiu Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemical Engineering, Liaoning Key Lab for Energy Materials and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, 116024, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals School of Chemical Engineering Liaoning Key Lab for Energy Materials and Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemical Engineering, Liaoning Key Lab for Energy Materials and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, 116024, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Heteroatom doping is an effective strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of catalysts. In this study, we propose a series of heteroatom doping (P, O) MoS3 catalysts to investigate the effect of heteroatoms on the catalytic activity of these catalysts for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR). In P doping catalysts, the electron-donating ability of the Mo1 active site is improved by raising the P atom content, and N2 is activated by the π*-acceptation effect. In O doping catalysts, the electron-accepting ability of the Mo1 active site is improved by raising the O atom content, meanwhile, the N2 activation process transforms from the π*-acceptation effect to the σ-donation effect. The reaction mechanism of the catalysts can be accurately depicted under the constant-potential method, the calculated results elucidate that the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst with a tiny amount of O atom exhibits good catalytic activity for eNRR with the limiting potential of -0.43 V vs. RHE. Additionally, the E ads(*N2) and E ads(*NNH) can be served as the descriptors to understand the origins of catalytic activity for the catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heteroatom doping MoS3 N2 activation process Constant-potential method Reaction mechanism Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3), with its high hydrogen content (17 wt%) and energy density (3 kWh kg−1), can be directly used as fuel and is considered a future hydrogen storage method, which is widely used in medicine, the chemical industry, agriculture, and other fields [1,2]. In industry, the Haber-Bosch process is mainly used to synthesize ammonia on a large scale. This process consists of nitrogen and hydrogen reacting at high temperatures (400–450 °C) and high pressures (15–25 MPa) and emitting a large amount of carbon dioxide [3–5]. As such, a new method of synthesizing ammonia under mild conditions needs to be developed. At present, ammonia synthesis methods mainly include photocatalysis [6], chemical looping [7], electrocatalysis [8], etc. The electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) is considered an efficient, clean, and sustainable ammonia synthesis strategy under ambient conditions, due to its high energy efficiency and zero greenhouse gas emissions [9]. The eNRR is a process of six net coupled proton and electron transfer (N2 + 6H++ 6e−→ 2NH3). This reaction process involves the transfer of H+, which may produce hydrogen [10,11]. Nitrogen molecule is very stable and the NN triple bond energy is 945 kJ·mol−1. As such, eNRR has to solve the problem of N2 activation and is also hindered by the competition of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [12–15]. Biological nitrogen fixation methods usually employ nitrogenase to reduce N2 to NH3 under mild conditions. Among them, Mo and S in nitrogenase play an important role, and the Mo atom acts as an active site to adsorb the N2 molecule [16]. Based on this characteristic of nitrogenase, Mo single-atom catalysts [17] and molybdenum sulfide (MoS x ) were used in the study for eNRR from both experimental and computational perspectives. Chen et al. demonstrated that the adjacent Mo atom pairs porous in atomic layered molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) catalyst including can effectively reduce the activation energy of the NN triple bond [18]. Sun et al. reported that the positively charged Mo atoms in MoS2 nanosheets and defect-rich MoS2 nanoflower catalysts are the keys to the activation of the N2 molecule [19,20]. It has been proved that the defect MoS2 catalyst rich in Mo atoms transfers more electrons to N2, thus promoting the progress of eNRR [21]. The metastable MoS2 catalyst with high local electron density was reported by Huang et al., which transferred more electrons to N2 and enhanced the adsorption of N2 [22]. The heteroatom doping MoS2 would change the electronic structure of the active site, thus improving the activation ability of N2 and the catalytic performance. It was demonstrated that both the N-doped MoS2 nanoflower catalyst [23] and the P-doped MoS2 catalyst [24] facilitated electron transfer related to eNRR and enhanced the activation ability of N2. Compared with MoS2, the unique molecular structure of one-dimensional disordered chain-like MoS3 possesses abundant active unsaturated Mo sites, which provide abundant active sites for the reaction and facilitate electrons transfer [25,26]. Chu et al. revealed the strong electron-donating effect of a disordered chain-like MoS3 catalyst was beneficial to transfer electrons to N2, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst for eNRR [27]. Our group proposed the poor crystalline MoS x /CNT catalyst with a Mo/S atomic ratio of about 1:3, which adjusts the electronic structure of the Mo atoms according to the electronegativity difference between O and S atoms [28]. The results showed that the modified MoS x exhibited excellent eNRR catalytic performance, and the faradaic efficiency and NH3 yield were ∼2 times higher than that of the original MoS x . Therefore, it is still unclear which type of heteroatom and atomic ratio of doping MoS x can enhance the catalytic activity of the active site for eNRR, which is necessary for us to investigate. In this study, we construct a one-dimensional MoS3 structure based on the literature reported [29]. Through doping the O (χ = 3.44) atom and P (χ = 2.19) atom with different electronegativity values from the S atom (χ = 2.58) in the MoS3 catalyst, a series of heteroatom doping MoS3 catalysts with different dopants and different atomic ratio are constructed. The electronic structure of the active site in a series of heteroatom doping MoS3 catalysts and the activation process of N2 over these catalysts are investigated to explore their activity-structure relationship. Additionally, to evaluate the effect of the type of doped heteroatom, electrode potential and pH on the catalytic activity of the catalysts for eNRR, we adopt the constant-charge and constant-potential methods to investigate the eNRR mechanism over the catalysts. In addition, both E ads(*N2) and E ads (*NNH) are chosen to establish the relationship with the U L of eNRR to analyze the origins of catalytic activity for the catalysts. 2 Computational method In this work, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are performed using the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotential [30] provided in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [31,32] and all calculations consider the spin polarization. Generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [33] was employed to describe the exchange and correlation interactions, and the van der Waals interaction was considered by the empirical correction of the Grimme's scheme (DFT-D3) [34]. The cut-off energy for plane waves was set to 520 eV. The convergence accuracy of total energy during geometry optimization is set at 10−4 eV and the force between atoms was less than 0.05 eV/Å. The Brillouin zone was sampled by a Gamma-centered 3 × 3 × 3 Monkhorst-Pack grid for all calculations. The charge transfer was analyzed by the Bader charge analysis [35] method. The MoS3 model (6 Mo and 18 S atoms) consists of aggregates of the Mo3S9 cluster with the lattice of 13.35 Å × 12.57 Å × 15.38 Å. Ab initio molecular dynamics simulations (AIMD) are performed in the canonical ensemble (NVT) with Nosé-Hoover thermostat at 298 K for a time period of 10 ps to verify the thermodynamic stability of the catalysts. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG) is calculated by the following equation: Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U where ΔE, ΔZPE, T, ΔS, ΔGU and are the difference of the energy of the reaction intermediate before and after adsorption, the zero-point energy, the temperature (298.15 K in this work), the entropy difference between products and reactant and the free energy contributed by electrode potential, respectively. For the gas-phase molecule (N2, H2, and NH3), the entropy correction was taken from the standard values of thermodynamics [36]. In addition, the limiting potential (U L) can be calculated by the following equation: U L = − Δ G m a x / e where ΔG max and e are the Gibbs free energy and the number of electron transfers in the potential-determining step of the reaction, respectively. We simulated the effects of solvation and applied potential on the reaction by using the double reference method [37,38], and the effects of aqueous solutions were carried out under an implicit solvation model by using the VASPsol code [39,40]. To simulate the reaction under different applied electrode potentials, excess charges from −2e to 2e are applied to each structure with a step size of +0.5e. The potential of the slab reference to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) is U q ( V / SHE ) = − 4.6 V − Φ q / e where − Φ q is the work function of the charged slab and -4.6 V is the work function of the H2 / H+ couple at standard conditions. The total energy of the charged system is defined as E = E DFT − Δ n ( V sol + Φ q / e ) where E DFT , Δ n , and V sol are the energy of DFT calculated, the number of excess charges, and the electrostatic potential of the bulk electrolyte, respectively. And the relationship between E(Uq ) and Uq follows the quadratic function as E ( U q ) = − 1 / 2 C ( U q − U 0 ) 2 + E 0 where U 0, C, and E 0 are the values of the potential of zero charge (PZC), the capacitance of the system, and the energy of the system at the PZC, respectively. The pH can influence the catalytic performance of catalysts by changing the electrode potential. In this study, we employed pH = 13 to analyze the eNRR catalytic activity on the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 The stability and structure properties of catalysts By replacing the shared, bridging and apical S atoms in the MoS3 catalyst (Figure S1a) with P or O atoms and adjusting the atomic ratio of X/S (X = P, O), P-doped MoS3 catalysts (MoS(9- x )/3P x /3, x = 1–4) and O-doped MoS3 catalysts (MoS(9- x )/3O x /3, x = 1–8) are constructed, the geometrically optimized structures are shown in Figure S1b. The bond lengths between Mo atoms and non-metallic atoms in the MoS(9- x )/3P x /3 (x = 1–4) catalysts are no significant change compared with that of in the MoS3 catalyst, but that are shortened by about 0.5 Å in the MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 1–8) catalysts (Figure S1b). To evaluate the stability and experimental feasibility of these catalysts, the binding energies (E b) and formation energies (E f) of MoS(9- x )/3P x /3 (x = 1–4) and MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 1–8) catalysts are calculated, the negative E b and E f values (Fig. 1 b) indicated that the good stability and experimental feasibility of these catalysts. To further inspect the thermodynamic stability of catalysts, the AIMD simulations are performed at 298 K for the MoS3, MoS8/3P1/3, MoS8/3O1/3 and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts with the time period of 10 ps, the atomic structure of these catalysts are well preserved, the temperature and energy fluctuate in a small range, illustrating that these catalysts exhibit high thermodynamic stability (Fig. 1c and Figure S2). The adsorption energies (E ads) of the N2 molecule on all possible adsorption sites in the MoS3 catalyst (Fig. 1a) indicate that the Mo1 atom has the lowest E ads than other sites (Table S1), and the N2 molecule is preferably adsorbed on the Mo1 atom. Hence, the Bader charge analysis of the Mo1 atom in MoS3, MoS(9- x )/3P x /3 (x = 1–4), and MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 1–8) catalysts are carried to describe the electronic structure of the Mo1 active site (Fig. 1d), the negative value indicates that charge transfers from the Mo1 atom to the surrounding atoms. Compared to the charge transfer between the Mo1 atom and the surrounding S atoms in the MoS3 catalyst, the charge transfer capacity of the Mo1 atom in the MoS(9- x )/3P x /3 (x = 1–4) catalysts to the surrounding P atoms is reduced, the Mo1 atom in the MoS(9- x )/3P x /3 (x = 1–4) catalysts is charge enriched. In contrast, for the MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 1–8) catalysts, the increase in O atoms content accelerates the charge transfer from the Mo1 atom to surrounding O atoms, to prompt the amount charge of the Mo1 atom to decrease. 3.2 N2 activation process The N2 molecule can be activated on the Mo1 active site via the "acceptance-donation" mechanism (Fig. 2 a), in which the empty d-orbital of the Mo atom can accept electrons from the σ-orbital of the N2 molecule (σ-donation), and the full d-orbital of the Mo atom can also donate electrons to the π*-orbital of the N2 molecule (π*-acceptation). The E ads of the N2 molecule adsorbed on the Mo1 active site of all catalysts with end-on and side-on configurations (Fig. 2b) are calculated, and the results indicate that the stable configuration for the N2 molecule is end-on configuration (Table S2). As such, the subsequent studies are dominated by the end-on configuration. The Bader charges of the N2 molecule adsorbed on the Mo1 active site are calculated to explore the activation process of the N2 molecule. As shown in Fig. 2c, the positive and negative values of the Bader charge indicate that the N2 molecule accepts the electrons from the Mo1 active site (π*-acceptation) and the N2 molecule donates the electrons to the Mo1 active site (σ-donation), respectively. The N2 molecule can accept the electrons from the MoS3, MoS(9- x )/3P x /3(x = 1–4) and MoS(9- x )/3O x /3(x = 1–5) catalysts, demonstrating the N2 molecule is activated via the π*-acceptation effect on these catalysts, which these catalysts exhibit electron-donating ability. By contrast, the N2 molecule donates the electrons to the MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 6–8) catalysts, indicating these catalysts activate the N2 molecule via the σ-donation effect, which these catalysts exhibit electron-accepting ability. The projected density of states (PDOS) of the MoS3, MoS8/3P1/3, MoS8/3O1/3, and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts with N2 adsorption are calculated (Fig. 2d), which these catalysts activate the N2 molecule with the different activation process. The hybridization of Mo1-d and N-p near the Fermi level demonstrates that both π*-acceptation and σ-donation effects can activate the N2 molecule. 3.3 eNRR mechanism using the CHE model The MoS3, MoS8/3P1/3, MoS8/3O1/3 and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts, which with different types of heteroatoms and different N2 activation processes, are selected to evaluate the catalytic activity of these catalysts for eNRR. The N2 molecule can be activated with end-on configuration on these catalysts, the study of the reaction mechanism for eNRR mainly considers two pathways, distal pathway and alternating pathway (Figure S4). The Gibbs free energies (ΔG) are calculated for each hydrogenation step through two pathways on the MoS3, MoS8/3P1/3, MoS8/3O1/3 and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts based on the computational hydrogen electrode method (CHE), which unconsidered the surface charge of the catalysts. The Gibbs free energy diagrams and all reaction intermediates are shown in Fig. 3 and Figures S5-S8. As shown in Fig. 3a, the first hydrogenation step (*NN + H + + e− → *NNH) is the potential determining step (PDS) through the distal pathway over MoS8/3P1/3 catalyst with the maximum Gibbs free energy (ΔG max) of 0.55 eV. The limiting potential (U L) of eNRR for MoS8/3P1/3 catalyst is −0.55 V, which is lower than that of other catalysts. Hence, the MoS8/3P1/3 catalyst exhibits better catalytic activity than other catalysts. Usually, the surface charge of the catalysts is nonzero, which is related to the electrode potential, and the catalytic activity of the catalyst is influenced by the electrode potential [41]. 3.4 eNRR mechanism using the CPM Based on the constant-potential method (CPM) [42,43], by varying the surface charge, the relationship between calculated energy and electrode potentials (referenced to the SHE scale) is established to obtain the energy for a specific electrode potential value (referenced to the RHE scale), the relationship between RHE and SHE is U RHE = U SHE + k B ln (10) pH / e. The calculated energies of the original catalysts and all corresponding reaction intermediates as a function of electrode potential are shown in Figs. 4 a and 5 a, all the energy-potential points are in good agreement with the quadratic relationship. At U = 0 V (vs. RHE), the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst exhibits better eNRR catalytic activity than other catalysts. Through the distal pathway, compared with the eNRR mechanism using the CHE model, the PDS over MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst is changed from the *NN + H + + e− → *NNH step to the first NH3 desorption step (*NNH2 + H+ + e− → *NNH3), the U L(NRR) is −0.46 V (vs. RHE) (Figs. 3b and 4b). Through the alternating pathway, the PDS over MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst is still the *NN + H + + e− → *NNH step and the U L(NRR) is −0.43 V (vs. RHE) (Figs. 3b and 5b). And the alternating pathway with a lower U L(NRR) value is the optimal reaction pathway for NRR over the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst. The reaction mechanism and catalytic activity of these catalysts for eNRR with electrode potential are different from those without electrode potential. In the case of considering the electrode potential, the calculation results are more consistent with the previous experimental results of our group, in which the modified MoS x catalyst by doping O atom presents better eNRR catalytic activity than the original MoS x and the P-doped MoS x catalysts. The Sabatier principle [44] states that catalysts with excellent catalytic activity have moderate adsorption on reaction intermediates. In the eNRR, the adsorption energy of *NNH (E ads(*NNH)) on the active site of the catalyst can be used as a descriptor to evaluate the catalytic activity of the catalyst [45]. As is shown in Fig. 6 , both the E ads(*N2) and E ads(*NNH) exhibit volcano-type relationships with the U L(NRR), where the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst locate at the peak of the volcano due to the suitable E ads(*N2) and E ads(*NNH), rationalizing the origins of excellent catalytic activity for the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst. Additionally, the desorption of NH3 from the catalyst surface plays an important role in the eNRR, which affects the performance of catalysts. As is shown in Figs. 4b & 5b, although the desorption of NH3 from the catalyst surface demands a large amount of energies (0.9 ∼ 1.3 eV), the energies released by the hydrogenation reaction in the early stages (1.65 ∼ 2.14 eV) are sufficient to desorb NH3. As such, the NH3 can desorb from the catalyst surface and the catalysts are not be poisoned by NH3 [46,47]. 3.5 The selectivity of catalysts The HER is the main competitive reaction for the eNRR. The active site of HER may be either metal atoms or non-metallic atoms [48–50]. The Gibbs free energy of the H atom adsorb on the Mo1 atom as well as the non-metallic atoms coordinated with the Mo atom of MoS3, MoS8/3P1/3 MoS8/3O1/3 and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts are calculated by using the CHE model (Figures S9 and S10a). The results indicate that the optimal adsorption site is different for each catalyst, the optimal site is selected to investigate the reaction mechanism of HER using the CPM (Figure S10b and Fig. 7 a). As is shown in Fig. 7b, the U L values of eNRR for the MoS8/3O1/3 and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts are lower than that of HER, which indicate that eNRR is more favorable than HER on MoS8/3O1/3 and MoS1/3O8/3 catalysts. Above the results, the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst with a lower U L(NRR) exhibits better eNRR catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion In summary, we adopt the P and O atoms with different electronegativity values to modulate the electronic structure of the Mo1 active site in the MoS3 catalyst and explore the catalytic activity of the catalysts for the eNRR. The Bader charge analysis of a series of catalysts (MoS3, MoS(9- x )/3P x /3 (x = 1–4), MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 1–8)) with a different number of dopants and doping sites are carried using DFT. Our results indicate that the doping of P atoms with a smaller electronegativity value compared with the S atoms increases the amount of charge of the Mo1 active site in the catalysts, while the doping of O atoms with a larger electronegativity value than the S atoms reduces the amount charge of the Mo1 active site. The type and number of heteroatoms doped in the catalysts can transform the activation process of the N2 molecule, it is proved that the P atoms doping, a tiny amount of O atoms doping, and MoS3 catalysts activate the N2 molecule via π*-acceptation effect, and MoS(9- x )/3O x /3 (x = 6–8) catalysts with a high O/S atomic ratio activate the N2 molecule via σ-donation effect. Subsequently, four catalysts (MoS3, MoS8/3P1/3, MoS8/3O1/3, MoS1/3O8/3) according to the type of heteroatoms and their different activation process of N2 molecule are selected to investigate the effects of electrode potential and catalyst structure on the eNRR activity of the catalysts. The results reveal that the U L of the eNRR process over the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst (−0.43 V vs. RHE) with considering the electrode potential is lower than the U L(NRR) of the MoS8/3P1/3 catalyst (−0.55 V) without considering the electrode potential. Interestingly, the eNRR catalytic activity exhibit correlation between the adsorption energies of reaction intermediates on the catalysts. It is demonstrated that the N2 can be easily converted into NH3 over the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst, which is consistent with the trend of experimental results. We can better comprehend the mechanism of the electrocatalytic reaction by taking into account the electrode potential in the theoretical research. Appendix A. coredata.dc:description: Heteroatom doping is an effective strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of catalysts. In this study, we propose a series of heteroatom doping (P, O) MoS3 catalysts to investigate the effect of heteroatoms on the catalytic activity of these catalysts for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR). In P doping catalysts, the electron-donating ability of the Mo1 active site is improved by raising the P atom content, and N2 is activated by the π*-acceptation effect. In O doping catalysts, the electron-accepting ability of the Mo1 active site is improved by raising the O atom content, meanwhile, the N2 activation process transforms from the π*-acceptation effect to the σ-donation effect. The reaction mechanism of the catalysts can be accurately depicted under the constant-potential method, the calculated results elucidate that the MoS8/3O1/3 catalyst with a tiny amount of O atom exhibits good catalytic activity for eNRR with the limiting potential of -0.43 V vs. RHE. Additionally, the E ads(*N2) and E ads(*NNH) can be served as the descriptors to understand the origins of catalytic activity for the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Modulating the electronic structure of MoS3 catalyst via heteroatom doping for Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction: A theoretical study
